title: 111_hr3840
content: The "Strengthening America's Satellite Industry Act" requires the President to enhance national and international arms export controls through diplomatic efforts. Congress urges the President to establish a senior-level initiative to ensure these controls align with U.S. standards, especially for countries of concern. The President must submit annual reports on these diplomatic efforts to relevant congressional committees. The amendment to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 requires reporting on unlicensed exports under the Arms Export Control Act, specifying exemptions under the International Traffic in Arms Regulations. SEC. 4. REPORT ON VALUE OF MAJOR DEFENSE EQUIPMENT AND DEFENSE ARTICLES EXPORTED UNDER SECTION 38 OF THE ARMS EXPORT CONTROL ACT. Section 38 of the Arms Export Control Act is amended to require the President to report the total dollar value of defense equipment exported by country and international organization for the previous fiscal year to specific congressional committees. This report must be included in the annual budget information submitted to Congress. SEC. 5. AUTHORITY TO REMOVE SATELLITES AND RELATED COMPONENTS FROM THE UNITED STATES MUNITIONS LIST. The President is authorized to remove satellites and related components from the United States Munitions List, except those that may be transferred to or launched by China. The effective date for this authority is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. REVIEW AND REPORT OF INVESTIGATIONS OF VIOLATIONS OF SECTION 3 OF THE ARMS EXPORT CONTROL ACT. The Inspector General of the Department of State will review investigations from fiscal years 2010 through 2014 for violations of the Arms Export Control Act. The review will determine if the Department of State complied with reporting requirements for unlawful use of US defense items by foreign countries. The Inspector General will submit a report to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations will receive a report for fiscal years 2010 through 2014 containing findings from a review conducted by the Inspector General of the Department of State. The report will be submitted in unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 90 days outlining options for making the export licensing functions of the Department of State's Directorate of Defense Trade Controls self-financing.
